newsitem.title: UK: London gold fixes barely changed in light business.
newsitem.headline: London gold fixes barely changed in light business.

text.p: Precious metals markets were steady and little changed on Friday afternoon as dealers stood by for the expiry of Comex traded options after the close in New York.
There was little reaction to a slightly lower opening on the New York futures as they reflected a recovery in the U.S. stock and bond markets following Thursday's fall.
"The options players have gold in a stranglehold at the moment," one dealer said referring to the yellow metal's likely $350-$355 per ounce price bracket for the day.
The Comex April contract was down $0.80 at $353.70 after Wall Street opened higher on the back of a deeper-than-forecast fall of 0.4 percent in the February Producer Price Index.
At the 1500 GMT fixing, gold was valued at $352.80 per ounce against $353.00 in the morning which was just 10 cents up on Thursday afternoon.
"There is still a lot of uncertainty about direction," one dealer said adding that clues were unlikely ahead of the option expiry.
Some dealers saw the price coming off a bit next week before the market gathered steam for another try on the upside.
"The upside has been quite thoroughly tested this week without making much of an impression," one dealer said.
Dealers noted liquidity was readily available and sub one percent one month lease rates suggested most of the short positions in the market since early this year had been covered.
Silver was around a cent or two higher at $5.27/$5.29 having attracted what some dealers considered technically related fund buying on Thursday.
A "golden cross" has formed on silver's chart where the 50 day moving average has crossed the 200 day as both lines ascend.
"It still looks pretty well capped around $5.32 and there is a problem with offers coming in at $5.30," one dealer said.
A $5.25-$5.32 range was suggested for silver but if it broke out it could run up to $5.45, a dealer said.
Platinum and palladium were barely changed but some dealers felt they were running out of steam.
A report overnight said that U.S. car makers had not revised palladium purchasing plans despite the market's 37 percent rise since its low last November.
Palladium prices have held since Russia's Almaz export agency said this week it would probably begin exports for this year later this month.
Palladium was up $0.25 at $151.75/$152.75 and platinum unchanged at $382.00/$383.00
